advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"With the Alice, change the level without changing the computer"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www1.cts.ne.jp/~sato/hp/">Sato's Homepage</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> STICKER</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a promotional adhesive sticker of the RC 700 Piccolo... What a visionary thought!</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert dated september 1983 says : <br><br> "<b>Orchidée : the fabulous computer</b> (!)<br> With Orchidee, discover you can drive a formula 1 computer and never open the hood. Orchidee offers power and speed of a real professional computer with, as a gift, a lot of innovations never yet combined : interchangeable processors, including the fabulous IAPX 186, removable software cartridges, mouse, light pen. Whether you are a computer specialist or not, you have a fabulous professional tool."</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #5</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> IEEE INTERFACE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> The Acorn IEEE interface enables full implementation of the IEEE standard 488-1978. IEEE488 is also known, and is equivalent to IEC625-1 (in Europe), and GPIB or HP-IB (Hewlett Packard General Purpose Interface Bus)...<br> ...The interface can support a network of up to 14 other IEEE-488 compatible devices. Devices can be interconnected in a star or linear fashion. </font><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8bs.com</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert dated december 1983, says: "A true computing system: 3590F".<br> 3590F was approx. 547 euros, which was cheaper than a TO-7 alone one year earlier. <br><br> This box contained: a TO-7 computer, Basic cartridge with doc, Joystick/Music expansion, 2 joysticks, TRAP game and PICTOR software. This was a special offer for christmas 83. <br><br> On the whole box is written: "A smart present for the whole family". </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>More power for less money</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (SEPT. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The amazing TI-99/4A.<br> A computer for 1800fr"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DISK DRIVE #2 FEB. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br><font color="#666666"> These 35-track, 51/4" double-density drives will give you the high-level performance you want from your Color Computer. Each drive puts over 156K of on-line data and program storage right at your fingertips. And you can chain up to four drives together for a total of more than 626K. <br><br> Yet all that extra storage is available at a seek time of 30 milliseconds and a data transfer rate of 250 bits per second...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> AN ADVERTISING</strong></font><br><blockquote>I couldn't resist putting this photo here. The girl looks very happy, the ad said "The new System III can be provided with walnut floor cabinet".</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> APPLE ACCESSORIES</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> There are more people in more places making more accessories and peripherals for Apples than for any other personal computer in the world.<br> Thanks to those people - in hundreds of independant companies - who can make the humblest 1978 Apple II turn tricks that are still on IBM's Wish List for 1984.<br> But now we're coming out with our very own line of peripherals and accessories for Apple personal computers... </font><br><br> The dual language of Apple: In the same advert, Apple thanks the companies manufacturing Apple compatible peripherals and asks its customers to buy only Apple peripherals in the future.... </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1980 ADVERT & PRICE LIST</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>Price list</b><br><br> <b>VP-111 </b>Low cost microcomputer <b>$99</b><br> <b>VP-114 </b>Expansion kit for VP-111 (3 KB RAM, I/O port and connectors) <b>$76</b><br> <b>VP-711 </b>Original VIP microcomputer <b>$199</b><br> <b>VP-44 </b>On board RAM expansion (4 x 2114 RAM chips) <b>$36</b><br> <b>VP-590 </b>Color board <b>$69</b><br> <b>VP-595 </b>Simple sound board (256 programmable frequencies) with speaker <b>$30</b><br> <b>VP-550 </b>Super sound board (Synthetiser with two sound channels <b>$49</b><br> <b>VP-551 </b>Super sound 4 channels expansion <b>$74</b><br> <b>VP-570 </b>4 KB RAM memory expansion board <b>$95</b><br> <b>VP-580 </b>Two players keypad <b>$20</b><br> <b>VP-585 </b>Keypad interface board <b>$15</b><br> <b>VP-560 </b>Eprom board for two 2716 EPROMS <b>$34</b><br> <b>VP-565 </b>2716 EPROM programmer with software <b>$99</b><br> <b>VP-575 </b>Expansion board with 5 expansions sockets <b>$59</b><br> <b>VP-700 </b>4 KB Tiny Basic <b>$39</b><br> <b>VP-701 </b>Floating point Basic (cassette) <b>$49</b><br> <b>VP-710 </b>Game listings <b>$10</b><br> <b>VP-720 </b>Game listings II <b>$15</b><br> <b>VP-601 </b>Keyboard 128-character ASCII <b>$69</b> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> ... With the knowledge that Mitsubishi is the largest manufacturer of Mainframe computers in Japan, those in the know will immediately recognise the true potential of the Mitsubishi F-series...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH (STUPID) PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Family life scene in front of a complete Atmos system carefully lined up on the coffee table in the living room, with a minimum of visible cables. <br><br> The flaw?... No, it is not that it is rather difficult to use such a serious configuration for hours sitting on the floor. The flaw comes rather from the photographer who forgot to do the housework before taking the picture and left to posterity his accessories cartons right behind the low dresser.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JACQUARD BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEAFLET (1982) - PAGE 2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice that the box arts are completely different from the final ones (see software section)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT. PAGE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is for the Micromachine 4000, but a picture of the Micromachine 2000 and 3000 is inserted.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>A computer for each job</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert for Victornet, the net for Victor computers, based on Omninet.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.cobit.kit.net" target="_blank">COB-Clube Old Bits</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MENTA & SOFTY ADVERT (FRANCE, SEPT. 82)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.description:
Photograph of the desktop console of the world's first microcomputer system. It utilized the Intel 8008 single-chip microprocessor.
The computer system was developed and manufactured by Q1 Corporation. They delivered the first microcomputer system to the Litcom Division of Litton Industries in Melville, Long Island on December 11, 1972 (and a second system in February, 1973). In April 1974 Intel introduced the second-generation, single-chip 8-bit microprocessor, the 8080. Until then, Q1 systems were the only self-contained, general-purpose microcomputer systems in the world.
In 1973, two limited-purpose products that utilized the 8008 were introduced: In May 1973 Micral, in France, introduced a special-purpose process controller; and in the fall, Jonathan Titus offered the Mark-8, an 8008 assembly-kit for the hobbyist market (Titus 1974). Neither product was, nor intended to be, a self-contained, general-purpose computer system.
In 1973, Q1 microcomputer systems were installed in Europe (Germany) and Asia (Hong Kong).
The Q1 System remained the world's only self-contained, general purpose microcomputer system until Intel introduced the 8080 second generation microprocessor.
Apparently, Q1 also delivered some of NASA's computers.
________
Source: Daniel Alroy and his website Philon.net
computer.name: Q1 System
